title: Fighting Fair
description: Explore whether conflicts stay within healthy boundaries

questions.text: There are unspoken rules about what's off-limits in our arguments.

therapeutic.rationale: Healthy couples have implicit or explicit rules about fighting fair—lines that won't be crossed even in anger. These boundaries protect the relationship from conflict damage.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't sense fair-fighting rules, discuss what should be off-limits. Making boundaries explicit creates shared understanding.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared understanding of boundaries creates safety during conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's off-limits in your arguments? Are these rules clear to both of you?

questions.text: We argue about the issue at hand, not everything at once.

therapeutic.rationale: Staying on topic keeps conflicts resolvable. When arguments expand to include every grievance, they become overwhelming and nothing gets resolved.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If conflicts expand beyond the issue, notice when that happens and gently redirect. 'Can we focus on this one thing right now?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to stay on topic creates focused, productive conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do your arguments stay focused or expand? What triggers the expansion?

questions.text: Neither of us threatens the relationship during arguments.

therapeutic.rationale: Threats to leave or end the relationship create profound insecurity. Using breakup as leverage in arguments damages trust and makes every conflict feel existential.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If relationship threats occur, they need direct attention. This pattern creates trauma and prevents healthy conflict. Committing to stop is essential.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual commitment to not threatening the relationship creates security.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Has leaving ever been threatened during arguments? What impact has that had?

questions.text: Our conflicts don't get physical or include destroying things.

therapeutic.rationale: Physical aggression and destruction are never acceptable in conflict. These behaviors indicate need for professional help and create lasting harm.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If physical aggression or destruction occurs, this is a serious concern requiring immediate attention, possibly including professional intervention.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared commitment to non-violent conflict is a fundamental relationship requirement.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Have conflicts ever become physical or destructive? What support might help?

questions.text: I feel safe during our arguments, even when they're heated.

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling safe during conflict is foundational. When safety is present, disagreements can be productive. When it's absent, survival mode prevents resolution.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel safe, this is priority one. Explore what creates danger—real or perceived—and address it directly.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual feeling of safety during conflict creates the conditions for resolution.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you feel safe during arguments? What would help you feel safer?
